3.0, but whatever you call it,

So we've been exploring space

The way we explored
space changed over time. So let's look back quickly.

What we call exploration 1.0,
that's basically a decade that

leads up to the Apollo
landing in late '50s to '60s.

During this decade, we send
like 20 missions to the moon,

out of which only
eight were successful. So the exploration 1.0 was
basically a fast paced trial

and errors, and that was it. But trial and error was
actually a very efficient way

of learning new
capabilities, as you know. And that was possible
for the moon. That was a completely valid
way to do for the moon

because it's just
three days away and the launch opportunity
comes up every month, basically.

However, this way
does not work for Mars

simply because it takes 6
to 7 months to get there and the launch window opens
up once in every 26 months.

So you cannot try and fail
every month for months. That's why we employ a
different approach, which

we call exploration 2.0. In the past three decades, we
sent 14 spacecraft to Mars, out

of which 11 were successful. So we were more cautious than
what we used to be for the moon.

But being cautious is not really
the point of the 2.0 model. The real point is
that we incrementally

sophisticated the
robotic capabilities through the series of missions
by building upon the knowledge

that we obtained from
the previous missions. For example, I wrote the flight
software of the autonomous

driving for Mars. That was one of the things I
did that I'm most proud of.

And it was enormously
successful. The way we've been

partially to build upon
the intricate environmental

knowledge that we already

of this new algorithm, we
used all the drive data from prior rover curiosity.

And when we evaluated

and ran Monte Carlo

that if we've been successful

on Mars, the way
we've been successful was to build upon the existing
knowledge about the environment.

So conceptually, this is
how this 2.0 paradigm works.

Initially, you don't know
anything about the environment. So the environmental
uncertainty is very high.

Therefore, you start with low
risk, low complexity mission. Maybe orbiter to
learn a little bit

about the surface environment. And then using

mission to the surface to learn more about
the environment.

Now, once you know enough

return that we are

2.0 style paradigm

has been enormously
